A French farmer's distress: 'I found the first dead cow when I went to the pasture'
subhead: Near Benque, a village an hour from Toulouse, farmer Christian Lasserre discovered three carcasses on Saturday. He fears a new outbreak of lumpy skin disease and the culling of the entire herd.

Sarkozy faces possible indictment over witness tampering
subhead: Former president Nicolas Sarkozy faces fresh legal troubles, as prosecutors said they plan to indict him, his wife, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, and nine others for allegedly tampering with witnesses in the Libya campaign-funding case. The Sarkozys could each face up to 10 years in prison.

headline: Inside one of New York's 'community kitchens,' at the forefront of the US cost-of-living crisis
subhead: In the world's largest economy, where prices for consumer goods, including food, have soared since the Covid-19 pandemic, 41 million people rely on government-issued food stamps to eat enough every day.

headline: Magdalena Abakanowicz's textile sculptures come to the Musée Bourdelle
subhead: The Parisian institution presents an exhibition of 70 works, entitled 'The Fabric of Existence,' dedicated to the Polish visual artist.

headline: 'Academic freedom at risk': The Danish university shaken by an anti-immigration cabal
subhead: Roskilde University found itself at the center of controversy over its programs, which were accused by both the far right and Social Democratic Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of being a backdoor route to immigration for foreign students.

subhead: Populism has never been stronger in France, but there is a crucial difference between flattering the people and serving them, and the Rassemblement National is currently stumbling on that divide, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

headline: 'Zack Polanski effect' has UK Greens closing gap on Labour
subhead: The unconventional profile of the new leader of Britain's Green Party, who embraces 'eco-populism' and has made social justice a central focus, has allowed his historically marginal party to claim the political space to the left of Labour.

headline: France's new cocaine users are everyday men and women
subhead: Contrary to what the French president has previously claimed, cocaine use now extends far beyond wealthy city-center elites.
